title: Alabama Beef Systems Videos: How to Collect a Hay Sample

tasks.task: Collecting and analyzing hay samples for nutritional assessment
subtasks: Determine the need for forage analysis
Gather necessary equipment for sampling
Collect hay samples using a forage probe
Insert probe at appropriate angles (90 degree angle for round bales, center for square bales)
Remove probe and empty into mixing bucket
Mix collected samples thoroughly
Take a sub-sample into a labeled bag
Complete an analysis form and submit with sample to a certified laboratory
Wait for test results within a two to three week period
Use the nutritional report to plan feed resources and supplementation
Consult with local extension agents for assistance
Obtain a forage probe from the county extension office
Operate the forage probe using an electric drill
Sample multiple bales within each hay lot
Properly label the sample bag with relevant information
Accurately fill the sample bag to at least half full
Define a hay lot (same harvest, field, conditions)
Collect 15-20 core samples from each bale within a lot
For round bales, sample the curved side towards the center
For square bales, insert into the center of the end
Correctly detach the probe and avoid cross-contamination

tasks.task: Understanding the process for feed resource decision-making
subtasks: Recognize the purpose of forage analysis in livestock nutrition
Interpret the nutritional value report from the lab
Develop a supplementation plan based on test results
Utilize management practices to optimize feed efficiency
